text: I am fed up, frustrated and scared. Because despite understanding statistics I still see the same glaring headlines again and again. It’s time for more responsible reporting of statistics and I have some ideas for how this can happen.
translation: 我受够了，沮丧和害怕。 因为尽管了解统计数据，但我仍然一次又一次看到相同的标题。 现在该是更负责任的统计报告了，我对如何做到这一点有一些想法。

text: A Way Forward…On Some Conditions
translation: 前进的道路……在某些情况下

texts: For the reader: Learn what an unconditional probability tells you. When we hear about a mortality rate of 3.4%, what we are actually being told is that of all the people who have contracted COVID-19, 3.4% of them have died (past tense). It does not mean that in a room of 100 people with covid, 3 people will die. Unconditional probabilities can tell us about the past and can tell us simple statistics that leave out important and vital information. Unconditional probabilities should never be used to make claims about the future.

For the media: Stop reporting unconditional probabilities. Instead try: “less than 1% of those contracting COVID-19 who are under the age of 65 have died” or “less than 1% of people without underlying health conditions have died from COVID-19”. Of course, this risks separating readers by age and health, but it’s a start.

For the media: Okay so you probably won’t stop, but if you insist on continuing to report unconditional probabilities, you must emphasise exactly what they do and what they do not represent. Emphasise the past-tense, not the future — “3.4% have died”. Emphasise a lack of knowledge — “3.4% of reported cases have died but this number depends on personal circumstances” (okay that one is less catchy but you get the idea).
translations: 对于读者：了解无条件概率告诉您什么。 当我们听说死亡率为3.4％时，实际上是在告诉所有感染COVID-19的人，其中3.4％死了（过去时）。 这并不意味着在有100个人的情况下，会有3个人死亡。 无条件的概率可以告诉我们过去，也可以告诉我们简单的统计信息，而忽略了重要和重要的信息。 无条件概率绝不能用于对未来进行索赔。
对于媒体：停止报告无条件概率。 而是尝试：“在感染COVID-19的65岁以下人群中死亡的比例不到1％”或“在没有基本健康状况的人群中，只有不到1％的人群因COVID-19死亡”。 当然，这有可能按年龄和健康状况区分读者，但这是一个开始。
对于媒体：好吧，所以您可能不会停下来，但是如果您坚持要继续报告无条件概率，则必须准确强调它们的作用和不代表的情况。 强调过去时态，而不是未来时态：“ 3.4％的人死亡”。 强调缺乏知识-“ 3.4％的已报告病例已死亡，但这一数字取决于个人情况”（好吧，虽然不那么吸引人，但您可以理解）。

text: Coronavirus and Probability — The media must learn how to report statistics now
translation: 冠状病毒和概率—媒体必须立即学习如何报告统计信息

text: With widespread panic around COVID-19, the media must learn the difference now between two hugely different statistics.
translation: 随着围绕COVID-19的普遍恐慌，媒体现在必须了解两种截然不同的统计数据之间的区别。

text: The phrase “underlying symptoms” crops up in almost all news stories in which someone dies from what seems a common incident. Whether it’s an allergy-sufferer, or a victim of coronavirus (‘covid’), the “underlying symptoms” phrase is used to lessen fear. Being an unfortunate combination of both a hypochondriac and a statistician, whenever I see a news article like this I immediately skim to find the relevant line and think to myself “phew, I’m okay then”. Of course this is incredibly self-centred thinking. But as long as unconditional probabilities are reported in the media, the public’s (well certainly my) sense of personal danger is heightened.
translation: 在几乎所有新闻报道中都会出现“潜在症状”这一短语，其中有人死于看起来很常见的事件。 不管是过敏患者还是冠状病毒（“ covid”）的受害者，“潜在症状”都是用来减轻恐惧的。 作为下位症和统计学家的不幸组合，每当我看到这样的新闻文章时，我都会立即浏览并找到相关内容，然后对自己说：“ phe，那我可以。” 当然，这是难以置信的以自我为中心的思维。 但是，只要媒体报道了无条件的概率，公众（当然是我）的人身危险感就会增强。

text: Unconditional vs. Conditional Probability
translation: 无条件与条件概率

text: To better explain the problem I’m talking about, we’re going to have to look at the stats a little bit, I’ll keep it as basic as possible here, later we will go into a bit more detail.
translation: 为了更好地解释我正在谈论的问题，我们将不得不稍微看一下统计数据，在这里我将其保持为尽可能基本，稍后我们将进行更详细的介绍。

text: Let’s say we want to predict the probability of a die landing on the number 6 when thrown, we want to know:
P(Die = 6)
translation: P（模具= 6）

text: Which is read as “the probability that a die equals 6”. Now say we want to predict the probability of a die landing on the number 6, given that we know (for whatever reason) that it must land on a number greater than 3. Then we want to know:
translation: 读作“骰子等于6的概率”。 现在，假设我们知道（无论出于何种原因）骰子必须降落在大于3的数字上，我们要预测骰子降落在6上的概率。那么我们想知道：

text: P(Die = 6 | Die > 3)
translation: P（模具= 6 |模具> 3）

text: Where the vertical line “|”, means “given that”.
translation: 垂直线“ |”表示“给定”。

text: The difference between these two equations is that the first is unconditional — we want to know the probability of an event occurring given no other information — and the second is conditional — we want to know the probability of an event occuring and conditioned on (or “given”) some other condition or event.
translation: 这两个方程式的区别在于，第一个方程式是无条件的-我们想在没有其他信息的情况下知道事件发生的可能性-第二个方程式是有条件的-我们想知道事件发生的可能性并取决于（或“ 给定”）其他条件或事件。

translation: 换句话说：给定某个事件B，事件A发生的概率等于给定事件A发生事件B的概率，再乘以事件A的概率，再除以事件B的概率。 一口，所以让我们来看一个例子。
